title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in D (Shape: D)

# Dominant 7b5 Chord in D

The Dominant 7b5 chord, also known as the half-diminished seventh chord (7b5), is a four-note chord that consists of the root, major third, diminished fifth, and minor seventh. In the key of D, when we build a Dominant 7b5 chord on the note D, it includes the notes D-F#-Ab-C.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: D
- Major third: F#
- Diminished fifth: Ab
- Minor seventh: C

The intervals for the D Dominant 7b5 chord in D are: 1-3-b5-b7.

## Musical Genre and Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord in D is often used in jazz and jazz-influenced styles. It adds tension and dissonance to the harmonic progression, creating a sense of unease that can resolve nicely to a major or minor chord. The chord has a rich and sophisticated sound, making it a popular choice in more complex and colorful musical contexts.
